summary: A video tutorial on using GDB to debug a simple C program that calculates factorials.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a white screen that transitions to a grey background displaying the text "THIS IS CS50. CS50.TV" in black font. The scene then shifts to a man wearing a blue long-sleeve shirt standing against a white background. The text "GNU Project Debugger" appears on the left side of the screen. The man speaks directly to the camera, and the camera zooms in on his upper body and face, focusing on his expressions and gestures. The video maintains a simple and clean visual style, with the man as the central figure against the plain white background. The video concludes with the man still speaking, with the camera maintaining its close-up focus on him.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with the sound of an engine revving, possibly an industrial engine. This is followed by a single, male speaker, who sounds confident and excited about the subject, introducing "GDB, the GNU Project Debugger" as a "powerful debugging tool" for C, saying it allows you to "poke around inside your C programs." The speaker explains that GDB is free software that runs on different systems, and that pros "have a much easier time tracking down bugs".

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a blue long-sleeved shirt standing against a plain white background. He appears to be speaking, as his mouth moves and his facial expressions change throughout the video. The man's posture remains relatively static, with his arms hanging by his sides. At one point, the video transitions to a text screen displaying a command prompt and the GNU gdb (GNU Debugger) interface, indicating that the man might be discussing or demonstrating something related to programming or software development. The text on the screen includes copyright information, version details, and instructions for reporting bugs. The video then returns to the man, who continues to speak, maintaining the same background and attire. The overall atmosphere of the video is instructional, with a focus on the man's presentation and the technical content displayed on the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a single male speaker describing a command-line tool, explaining its use in a terminal with keyboard commands rather than a mouse. He gives instructions on how to start up GDB by typing "GDB" at the prompt, describing the output on the screen and the GDB prompt indicating readiness for commands.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker explaining that knowing how to quit is the most important thing. He describes the quit command and notes that "Q" can be used as a shortcut. He ends the clip with "And" said softly.

He appears to be explaining a concept, as he gestures with his hands and occasionally looks directly at the camera. events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins, stating his intention to use GDB to debug a program and introducing a program, factorial.c, designed to compute the factorial of an integer. He then explains what the factorial of a number is, providing examples with 3 and 4, and touches upon the edge cases of 0 and negative integers.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a blue long-sleeved shirt standing against a plain white background. He appears to be speaking, as his mouth moves and his facial expressions change throughout the video. At one point, text appears on the screen stating "(-n)! is undefined," which suggests that the man is discussing a mathematical concept related to factorials. The video then transitions to a computer screen displaying a command-line interface with a series of commands and outputs related to compiling and running a program named "factorial." The man continues to speak, likely explaining the process or the results shown on the screen. events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a male speaker discussing a "factorial program" and debugging it using "GDB" due to "weird numbers". The speaker's tone is conversational and slightly concerned.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a blue long-sleeved shirt standing against a plain white background. He appears to be speaking, as his mouth moves and his facial expressions change throughout the video. The man's posture remains relatively static, with his arms hanging by his sides. The video transitions to a series of text-based frames displaying a command-line interface. The text includes commands and responses related to the GNU Debugger (GDB), a software debugging tool. The commands and responses are shown in a monospaced font, typical of command-line interfaces, and include prompts and outputs related to debugging a program named 'factorial'. The text is displayed on a black background, with white text for readability. The video then returns to the man in the blue shirt, who continues to speak, maintaining the same posture and background. The video concludes with the man still speaking, with no significant changes in his appearance or the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker explaining how GDB operates, mentioning "executable files," "source code files," and the concept of running it instead on "factorial." He notes that if a program required command-line arguments, that would be the place to specify them. He continues by explaining how to start the factorial program running and how to interact with the GDB prompt. He then repeats the process and explains how GDB provides junk that cannot be accessed once the program has finished.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a light blue long-sleeved shirt standing against a plain white background. He appears to be speaking, as his mouth moves and his facial expressions change throughout the video. At one point, the word "breakpoint" appears in black text on the left side of the screen, indicating a possible reference to a technical or programming concept. The man's posture remains relatively static, with his arms hanging by his sides. The video then transitions to a series of frames displaying text on a black background, which appears to be a screenshot of a command-line interface related to the GNU Debugger (GDB). The text includes commands and outputs related to debugging a program named "factorial," with references to entering a positive integer and setting breakpoints. The video maintains a consistent focus on the man and the text, with no significant changes in the environment or background.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker in an informative tone, explaining debugging techniques using GDB, particularly focusing on breakpoints. He details how breakpoints pause the program to examine its state and how to set one at the beginning of the "main" function using the "break" command, which can be abbreviated as "b". The speaker reiterates how the program is now poised at the beginning of "main" and the "printf" line is the next to be executed.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing against a plain white background, wearing a light blue long-sleeve shirt. He appears to be speaking, as his mouth is open and his facial expression is animated. The scene then transitions to a close-up of a computer screen displaying a text editor with lines of code. The code is written in C and includes a function named 'factorial' that calculates the factorial of a given number. The man continues to speak, and the video alternates between his speech and the code on the screen. The code is shown in detail, with the man pointing out specific lines and explaining their functionality. The video maintains a focus on the man's explanation and the code, with no additional background details or objects visible. The man's gestures and facial expressions suggest he is providing a detailed explanation of the code's functionality. The video concludes with the man still speaking, with the code on the screen remaining visible.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker who is discussing how to use GDB. He mentions using the "next" command, describes how operating systems suppress writing to the screen, talks about looking at the source code with the "list" command, and explains how to use the "print" command to check variable values. The speaker's tone is informative and instructional.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing against a plain white background, wearing a light blue long-sleeved shirt. He appears to be speaking, as his mouth moves and his facial expressions change. The scene then transitions to a close-up of a computer screen displaying a programming code in a text editor. The code is written in C and includes a function to calculate the factorial of a number. The code is being debugged, as indicated by the "(gdb)" prompts and the line numbers. The debugger shows the execution of the code, with the variable "num" being set to 4 and the factorial being calculated. The video then returns to the man, who continues to speak, gesturing with his hands to emphasize his points. The plain white background remains consistent throughout the video, keeping the focus on the man and the code. The video concludes with the man still speaking, maintaining the same posture and expression.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker continues debugging by going through a loop bit by bit. He mentions, "rather than typing N each time, we can also just hit enter", saying the debugger will repeat the previous command. The speaker observes that it looks like the loop has gone through four times as intended. Something is not right as he gets a huge number. When printing the value of factorial, it contains a massive number. He says that at this point it's too late to fix anything, so restarts the program.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing against a plain white background, wearing a long-sleeved blue shirt. He appears to be speaking, as his mouth is slightly open and his facial expression is neutral. The scene then transitions to a close-up of a computer screen displaying a code editor with a C program written in it. The code includes a function to calculate the factorial of a number, with comments explaining the purpose of the program. The man continues to speak, and the camera alternates between shots of him and the code editor, suggesting that he is explaining the code. The video then shows a series of frames with the code editor open, displaying different parts of the code and the man's interaction with it, such as setting breakpoints and running the program. The man's gestures and facial expressions indicate that he is engaged in explaining the code's functionality and debugging process. The video concludes with the man still speaking, with the code editor visible in the background, emphasizing the educational nature of the content.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker suggesting a breakpoint in a program's main function, noting that "everything seems to be fine with reading in the int" and proposing to either jump ahead or set a breakpoint after a do-while loop. The speaker then decides to set the breakpoint after the loop. They specify setting a breakpoint at a line number, emphasizing the importance of including the file name to avoid confusion, especially when working with multiple files. They introduce the "continue" or "C" command to move ahead to the breakpoint. The clip ends with the same male speaker saying "Okay." The speaker's tone throughout the clip is informative and instructional.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a sequence of frames from a computer screen displaying a C programming code for calculating factorials. The code is presented in a text editor with syntax highlighting, and the user is interacting with the program using a debugger, indicated by the "gdb" command prompts. The code includes a main function that prompts the user to enter a positive integer, reads the input, and calculates the factorial of the entered number using a for loop. The debugger is set to break at specific lines, allowing the user to step through the code and inspect variable values. The user inputs the number 4, and the debugger pauses at the factorial calculation loop, showing the current value of the factorial variable. The video captures the process of debugging and executing the code, with the user navigating through the program's execution and inspecting the factorial calculation step by step. The environment is a typical coding setup with a text editor and a terminal window displaying the debugger output. The atmosphere is focused and technical, emphasizing the process of programming and debugging.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins, speaking in a clear, instructional tone, setting the scene at a "for loop". He suggests going another line into the loop and "printing variables" to assess the situation, wanting to confirm if a variable 'i' is indeed one.  After confirming that is "all good," he asks about a variable "factorial". His tone changes to one of concern and says something is "no good" because they have a "big negative number". He wonders aloud how that happened. Upon reviewing the code, the speaker realizes they "never initialized it" and suggests that trash data is likely the culprit, which will "definitely throw off our calculation".

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a light blue long-sleeve shirt standing against a plain white background. He appears to be speaking, as his mouth moves and his facial expressions change throughout the video. The man's posture remains mostly upright, with slight variations in his stance and hand positions. At one point, the video transitions to a close-up of a computer screen displaying a programming code editor with lines of code written in C++. The code includes a function named 'factorial' that calculates the factorial of a given number using a for loop. The editor shows the code being executed, with the debugger (GDB) providing information about the current state of the program, such as variable values and the line number where the program is currently executing. The video then returns to the man, who continues to speak, with the camera focusing on his upper body and face. The plain white background remains consistent throughout the video, emphasizing the man and the code editor. The video concludes with the man still speaking, maintaining the same posture and expression as he did at the beginning.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker with a clear, explanatory tone discussing debugging techniques. He mentions initializing values, fixing code later, and using print commands. He then references setting variables and continuing the program. He says he wants to make sure "everything's where it's supposed to be", checking variable values. He then introduces the "info locals" command to print local variables.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a sequence of frames displaying a computer screen with a code editor open, where a C program is being debugged using the GDB (GNU Debugger). The program calculates the factorial of a number, with the variable 'num' set to 4. The debugger's command line interface is visible, showing commands like 'p num' to print the value of 'num', 'p i' to print the value of the loop counter 'i', and 'info locals' to display the current values of local variables. The program's execution is paused at the line 'factorial = factorial * i;', and the debugger's output indicates that the factorial of 4 is 24. The environment is a typical development setup with a focus on the code and debugging process, and there are no people or other objects visible in the frames. The video captures the step-by-step process of debugging and executing the program, highlighting the interaction between the debugger and the code.
events_list.audio_caption: Two male speakers engage in a conversation about a programming loop. One speaker seems to be checking something, and the other responds positively and then mentions the "continue command". The first speaker expresses satisfaction by saying "sweet", and then notes the result of a calculation "4 factorial printed out 24, as expected".

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a blue long-sleeve shirt standing against a plain white background. events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker in an instructional tone discussing debugging code and using GDB. He mentions "quitting out of GDB," recompiling an executable, the "disable command," and restarting a program. The speaker describes that it is a "helpful tool" and that with "a little bit of practice" it can be easy. The clip concludes with the speaker giving their name and identifying the audio as "CS50".
